contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox mineral | name = Thortveitite | boxwidth = | boxbgcolor = | image = Thortveitite-ea14a.jpg | imagesize = | alt = | caption = Thortveitite | category = | formula = (Sc,Y)<sub>2</sub>Si<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> | strunz = | dana = | symmetry = | unit cell = | molweight = | color = | colour = | habit = | system = orthorhombic | twinning = | cleavage = | fracture = | tenacity = | mohs = 5-6 | luster = vitreous | streak = gray | diaphaneity = | gravity = 3.3-3.8 | density = | polish = | opticalprop = | refractive = | birefringence = | pleochroism = | 2V = | dispersion = | extinction = | length fast/slow = | fluorescence = | absorption = | melt = | fusibility = | diagnostic = | solubility = | impurities = | alteration = | other = | prop1 = | prop1text = | references = | var1 = | var1text = | var2 = | var2text = | var3 = | var3text = | var4 = | var4text = | var5 = | var5text = | var6 = | var6text = }} '''Thortveitite''' is a [[mineral]] consisting of [[scandium]] [[yttrium]] [[silicate]] (Sc,Y)<sub>2</sub>Si<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>. It is the primary source of scandium. Occurrence is in granitic [[pegmatite]]s. It was named after [[Olaus Thortveit]], [[Norway|Norwegian]] engineer. It is greyish-green, black or grey in color.
